node.description: Nodes can be connected to one another using one of the various types of connections. The two main divisions of nodes are DNA parts and molecular species.
Molecular species that diffuse through the cell, such as proteins, RNA, or metabolites.
Metabolites, ions, and other small molecules
Chain of amino acids.
Proteins that catalyze a metabolic reaction.

node.decription: proteins that bind to a regulatory site and influence the activity of the downstream promoter.

node.description: Receptors usually have a binding domain and can be localized on the plasma membrane.
Molecules that are used as indicators, such as fluorescent molecules.
RNA molecules
DNA nodes represent components that belong on a DNA strand, such as promoter, genes, etc.
Transcription factor binding site
RNA Polymerase binding site; may or may not include the operator sites, depending on the model
A promoter that is always active
A promoter that is requires a transcription factor for activation
A promoter that can be repressed by a transcription factor
A binding site that can be bound to activate the nearby promoter
A promoter with a binding site that requires a transcription factor for activation
A binding site that can be bound to repress the nearby promoter
A promoter with a binding site that can be repressed by a transcription factor
Ribosome binding site
Transcriptional terminator
A vector backbone, which contains a selectable marker, and an insert constitute a plasmid.
Sticky ends used for cloning
A region where the contained molecular species are localized and contained
A compartment inside a biological cell, e.g. nucleus
A biological cell, e.g. a bacterium
Degradation or dilution
